title: Kenya’s HIV patients, including children, on edge as US stops aid
description: At the Nyumbani Children's Home in Kenya's capital Nairobi, the facility's staff fears for the future of children with HIV/AIDS as US freezes foreign aid. Without U.S. funding, distribution from the Nairobi warehouse, which stocks all U.S. government-donated HIV medicine to Kenya, has ceased, leaving supplies of some drugs worryingly low, according to a former USAID official and a health official in Kenya. The 90-day foreign aid freeze, ordered by U.S. President Donald Trump has disrupted the global supply of HIV medicines as well as drugs for other diseases. Reuters’ Fiona Jones reports.

title: Kenya's Ruto, opposition veteran Odinga sign deal to form "broad-based government"
description: Kenyan President William Ruto and opposition veteran Raila Odinga on Friday signed a memorandum of understanding, formalizing what has been termed as a “broad-based government” at Nairobi’s Kenyatta International Convention Centre (KICC). The pact between the United Democratic Alliance, UDA, and the Orange Democratic Movement, ODM, details a framework for collaboration between the country’s two largest political parties. Both parties have pledged to work together on the East African nation’s many challenges including its ballooning debt and corruption. Ruto's popularity has been dwindling after plans for new taxes sparked massive youth-led protests in 2024 that saw at least 60 people killed, according to rights groups. The protests plunged Ruto's government into a crisis, forcing him to join forces with Odinga to form a "broad-based government" last year with several members of his party.

title: Museum of Illusions opens in Nairobi with an African-inspired twist
description: Kenya's urban street artists have teamed up to add an African-inspired twist to East Africa's first Museum of Illusions in Nairobi.

title: In Kenyan newsroom, a young generation joins the digital media trend
description: In Kenya, more and more audiences are consuming news via social media. The shift is changing the media landscape, with startups like Tuko emerging as a leader in fast-paced news for younger audiences. For VOA, Victoria Amunga meets the team to hear how they balance responsible journalism with the needs of the digital age.

title: Kenyan human rights group reports 82 cases of alleged forced disappearances since June 2024
description: Since June 2024, when a series of mass protests took place in Kenya, 82 cases of alleged forced disappearances have been recorded, according to the Kenyan National Human Rights Commission. It’s yet to be confirmed who is behind the abductions. VOA Nairobi Bureau Chief Mariama Diallo, who spoke to two brothers who say they were abducted for 32 days, has this report.

title: Kenyan jobseekers head abroad to help boost economy back home
description: Kenya's labor ministry says the government looks to send 1 million workers abroad a year for the next three years to countries where officials are hoping that young Kenyans can gain skills and income that will benefit the domestic economy. However, the initiative, one of the African country's biggest ever, is not without its detractors. Reuters’ Lauren Roback has this report.

title: Kenyan scientists study mealworm they say can break down plastics
description: Scientists in Kenya say they are studying a mealworm native to Africa that can consume and biodegrade plastic. Experts report the meal worm produces enzymes that can help break down plastic waste. Juma Majanga reports from Nairobi, Kenya. Camera: Amos Wangwa.

title: Kenyan brothers turn recycled newspapers into sustainable pencils
description: Kenyan brothers Mahamud and Rashid Omari are committed to doing what they can for the environment and running a successful business at the same time. The two are turning recycled newspapers into pencils. VOA's Patrick Wanjohi met the brothers to learn about their process and entrepreneurial journey.

title: US Embassy in Kenya unveils new tech hub for innovators
description: Kenyan startup innovators are accessing American libraries in their communities. The hubs dubbed American corner Mtaani meaning streets in Swahili enable young innovators to explore a wide range of technology and access eLibraryUSA. Victoria Amunga  reports from Nairobi.

title: 2024 World AIDS Day in Kenya
description: Communities around the world just commemorated World AIDS Day. In Kenya, one health facility provides affordable care to everyone, especially communities of people living with HIV. Reuben Kyama reports on this for VOA from the Kenyan capital Nairobi.

title: Kenya clinics provide healthcare to cross-border truck drivers, sex workers
description: A clinic initiative in Kenya aims to provide healthcare to vulnerable mobile populations, such as truck drivers and commercial sex workers. The goal is to combat the spread of disease across borders in Africa. Juma Majanga reports from transit town of Mlolongo in Kenya.

title: Kizza Besigye's attorney and others demand charges against him be dropped
description: In Uganda, Eron Kiiza, the defense lawyer for opposition figure Dr. Kizza Besigye tells VOA’s Peter Clottey that he is welcoming calls for charges against Besigye to be dropped. He says the family of Besigye and other human rights defenders plan to sue the Ugandan government for what he says were the violations of the rights of the opposition leader. Kiiza also says that the military court lacks jurisdiction to try the case in a military setting.

title: The Catholic Church in Kenya rejects donations pledged by President Ruto’s administration
description: Anti-tax Gen Z protesters in Kenya have welcomed the decision by the Catholic Church to reject cash donations and pledges by President William Ruto and his administration. Gen Z protester Robert Mwangi tells VOA’s Peter Clottey that the move shows the Catholic Church wants the government to be aware of the economic challenges facing many Kenyans.

title: How beekeeping is helps communities cope with climate change in Kenya
description: The U.N. Environment Program says communities living in drylands are the most affected by global warming, with frequent droughts and subsequent floods rendering traditional livelihoods like farming and livestock keeping nearly impossible. Conservation experts in Kenya are helping such communities develop climate-resilient alternative livelihoods like beekeeping to help them cope with the changing weather patterns. Juma Majanga reports from Garsen, Kenya.

title: AI app helps Kenyan farmers optimize crop yields
description: Farmers in Kenya are using artificial intelligence to help them get better crop yields. An AI-powered tool – called Virtual Agronomist – engages directly with farmers to help them create tailored plans to optimize the quality and quantity of their crops. Mohammed Yusuf has more from Mwea, Kenya.

title: Kenya’s impeached deputy president says his life is in danger
description: Kenya's impeached Deputy President Rigathi Gachagua told reporters Sunday that his security protection team had been withdrawn, and he warned that should anything happen to him, President William Ruto should be held responsible. Juma Majanga reports from Nairobi, Kenya.

title: Residents on Kenya’s coast use app to track migratory birds
description: The Tana River Delta on the Kenyan coast includes a vast range of habitats and a remarkably productive coastal ecosystem, says UNESCO. It is also home to many bird species, including some that are near threatened. Residents are helping local conservation efforts with an app called eBird. Juma Majanga reports.

title: Kenya hosts female gamers competition, winner to represent in DRC
description: Kenya is one of 16 African countries that have organized female gamers competitions this month. Kenya’s competition attracted at least 10 female gamers competing for a chance to represent the nation in the Democratic Republic of Congo next month. Mohammed Yusuf reports.

title: Kenya's VP says 70 children 'unaccounted for' after deadly school fire kills 17
description: Kenyan Vice President Rigathi Gachagua said Friday that 70 students remained ‘unaccounted for’ after a fire at a local boarding school killed 17 students and injured 13 others. Gachagua added that some of the students may have been taken home by their parents on the night of Thursday. The cause of the fire was not immediately clear. President William Ruto said he had told authorities to investigate what he called the "horrific incident" and said those responsible would be held to account. Authorities have cordoned off the school and crime scene investigators have been sent there. According to the East African nation’s ministry of education, the school has a total 824 students comprising 422 girls and 402 boys. Of these, 160 girls are boarders while the rest are day scholars.

title: China uses media trips in soft power play to boost image
description: Beijing is sending reporters to Chinese cities to showcase culture, technology and tourism. What’s missing, say analysts, is an uncensored picture of China and its human rights abuses. Victoria Amunga for VOA News has the story.

title: Sudan's Tokar cut off from Port Sudan by floods
description: Residents in South Tokar city in Sudan's Red Sea state were left stranded after flash floods destroyed the main highway connecting the city to de facto capital Port Sudan. People have been displaced and have lost their properties due to the floods. "People are going up and down using ropes. People are affected because of the property they lost and their belongings that were washed away by the flood," said local leader Taher Ohaj. Trucks have been parked on the destroyed road, unable to cross for the past eight days according to a local merchant, who added that prices have spiked after the floods due to the lack of access.

title: Kenya taxi drivers defy ride sharing rules, set their own fares to cope with higher cost of living
description: Some Kenyan taxi drivers have openly admitted to violating rules set by ride sharing companies like Uber, that prohibit their employees and contractors from setting their own fare prices, as a means of coping with the increased costs of living. Reuters reporter David Doyle has more.

title: Gen-Z protestors don't believe Kenya police chief nominee will keep promises
description: Robert Mwangi, a Gen-Z protester in Kenya says demonstrators do not believe that major police reforms promised by Douglas Kanja Kirocho, the nominee to become the inspector general of the police, will ever be carried out. Mwangi, tells VOA's Peter Clottey that public officials talk a good game but fail to keep their promises.

title: Restaurant with robot services causes excitement in Nairobi
description: In Nairobi, a new restaurant is generating business and buzz – not just because of the food, but because of the staff. Robots serving dishes is the main attraction of diners who flock to the Robot Café. Juma Majanga reports from Nairobi, Kenya. Camera: Jimmy Makhulo.

title: Restaurant with Robot Services Causes Excitement in Nairobi
description: In Nairobi, a new restaurant is generating business and buzz – not just because of the food, but because of the staff. Robots serving dishes is the main attraction for diners who flock to the Robot Café. Juma Majanga reports from Nairobi, Kenya.

title: Kenyan union official says upcoming teachers strike will disturb academic calendar
description: The Kenya National Union of Teachers and the Kenya Union of Post Primary Education Teachers are warning of an imminent industrial strike action to press home their demands for improved living conditions. Collins Oyuu, the secretary general of National Union of Teachers, tells VOAs Peter Clottey that the industrial action will interfere with the academic calendar.

title: Generation Z leading widely supported historic protests in Kenya
description: The recent protests in Kenya that forced the president to dissolve his cabinet have been led people under 27 years old, members of so-called Generation Z, many of whom identify as tribeless and classless. The nationwide protests are largely organized on social media with no notable leaders. They have snowballed into a movement calling for good governance, with broad backing across Kenya. So, who are these Gen-Z protesters? Juma Majanga reports from Nairobi, Kenya.

title: Kenya's Ruto names opponents to cabinet
description: Kenyan President William Ruto nominated on Wednesday four members of the main opposition party to a "broad-based" cabinet he promised in response to nationwide protests, but activists criticized the new government as a "corrupt bargain." Reuters’ Arrthy Thayaparan reports.

title: Kenya’s Gen-Z protesters say President Ruto’s new cabinet disappoints them
description: Kenya President William Ruto expressed concern that Gen-Z protesters are being sponsored by external forces to destabilize the country. However, the protesters say the new cabinet named by the president does not meet their expectations. Robert Mwangi is one of the Gen-Z protesters and talks with VOA’s Peter Clottey about some of his group's concerns.

title: At least one dead as Kenya protests intensify
description: Police clashed with protesters in Kenya on Tuesday in what appeared to be the biggest demonstrations since President William Ruto withdrew proposed tax hikes. Reuters’ David Doyle has more.

title: Kenyan transgender woman shares experiences of bullying, harassment
description: Model, talent manager, and motivational speaker, Letoya Johnstone David is a transgender woman who lives in Kenya. David recently met with reporter Anne Ngugi to share her story of facing harassment and bullying as the LGBTQI community continues to seek acceptance in the country.

title: Security expert finds Kenya’s security institutions are well structured
description: Richard Tutah, a security expert, says the immediate replacement after the resignation of Kenya's Inspector General of Police shows that the country’s security institutions are well structured. He also says there appears to be no evidence to prove that Kenyan police officers used excessive force against young people who protested against the recent finance bill. VOA's Peter Clottey spoke with Tutah.

title: Kenya's opulent lawmakers fuel a youthful backlash
description: The lavish lifestyles of some Kenyan lawmakers have prompted some activists to retaliate, ranging from attacks on their properties to efforts to have politicians recalled. Reuters’ David Doyle has more.

title: Kenya's Ruto dismisses almost entire cabinet after deadly protests
description: Kenyan President William Ruto announced on Thursday the dismissal of almost his entire cabinet as part of measures undertaken following widespread anti-government protests that turned deadly. He said the move with immediate effect affected all ministers except Prime Cabinet Secretary and Foreign Minister Musalia Mudavadi and Deputy President Rigathi Gachagua. The attorney general was also dismissed.

title: Kenya’s President Ruto establishes a taskforce to audit the country’s debt
description: Kenyan President William Ruto has established a taskforce to audit the country's public debt -- a key demand by Gen Z protesters. For analysis of the latest political developments, VOA's Peter Clottey reached Mark Bichache. He is a communication and political strategist with Dia Consult.

title: After a tax increase bill is withdrawn, Kenya’s President orders considerable budget cuts
description: Kenya President William Ruto has ordered significant cuts in the federal budget and proposed other government reforms to pay off a crushing debt burden. The move is seen as a concession to popular disapproval of a tax bill that sparked weeks of violent protests. VOA’s Nairobi Bureau Chief Mariama Diallo reports.

title: Rights groups say Kenyan protesters have been abducted
description: Human rights groups say dozens of Kenyans have been abducted in the past two weeks amid anti-government protests sparked by proposals to raise taxes. David Doyle of Reuters has more.

title: Youth protests against Kenya’s proposed tax increases continue
description: Kenya’s ongoing protests against proposed tax increases and the administration of President William Ruto are organized by citizens mostly in their 20s from the so-called Gen Z group. However, Members of other age groups are also expressing dissatisfaction with the government of East Africa’s biggest economy. VOA’s Darren Taylor reports.

title: Expert weigh in on fresh Kenya protest
description: A number of Kenyans have been killed after clashing with the police since June 18. On Tuesday, there was a heavy police presence in Kenya’s capital, Nairobi. The demonstrations started as an online anger over nearly $2.7 billion worth of tax hikes in a proposed finance bill that’s grown into a movement against corruption and irresponsible governance. VOA’s Paul Ndiho spoke to Adjunct Professor of African Studies at Georgetown University, James Ngundi about the situation.

title: Dr. Auma Obama on the future role of young people in Kenyan politics
description: Dr. Auma Obama is the founder and chairperson of the Auma Obama Foundation, Sauti Kuu, and an author, sociologist and sister to President Barack Obama, the 44th U.S. president. She tells VOA’s Peter Clottey that to know what young people are thinking you should listen to them since their anti-tax protests have nearly brought the country’s politics to a standstill.

title: Business, government count cost of Kenya's protests
description: Anti-government protests in Kenya have left some shops, like one belonging to Francis Ochieng, in ruins. But what also lies in tatters is Kenya's plan to tackle its heavy debt burden with IMF support. Reuters’ Kristy Kilburn has more.

title: Young adults leading protests against tax bill in Kenya
description: In Kenya, at least five protesters have been killed and dozens injured as a crowd stormed parliament during a protest against a bill raising taxes. Young Kenyans, mostly members of Generation Z, have been leading protests against the bill, giving political protests in Kenya a new face. Juma Majanga reports from Nairobi.

title: VOA 60: Heavy security surrounds Kenya’s parliament building after protests turn deadly, and more
description: A day after an anti-tax demonstration turned deadly in Nairobi, heavy security has been deployed around Kenya’s parliament building. A military court in the Democratic Republic of the Congo rejected a bid by defense attorneys to drop the trial of 51 people for an alleged May 19 coup attempt. This, and more Africa-related news updates on today’s VOA 60.

title: Ruto was whisked away to avoid confrontation with young anti-tax protesters
description: Kenyan President William Ruto had to be whisked away by his security team after he attended the consecration of a bishop in the town of Nyahururu Sunday. Local media reported that Ruto’s security team took the decision when they realized the crowds were there to confront him. Young anti-tax protesters had blocked vehicles belonging to leaders of Ruto’s ruling Kenya Kwanza party. Meanwhile, the Kenyan leader has praised young protesters and promised to engage with them amid demonstrations over his government’s plans to raise revenues through additional taxes. David Doyle of Reuters has more.

title: Important Kenyan financial institution affects lives in Africa
description: Equity Bank Kenya Limited is a prominent Kenyan bank that makes investments and affects lives in Africa. With a customer base of 20 million, it is the largest bank in the region. VOA's Paul Ndiho spoke to Dr. James Mwangi, Chief Executive Officer of Equity Group Holdings, about this financial institution.

title: Clean cooking initiative aims to cut indoor air pollution in Africa
description: Traditional cooking fuels and technologies are among the major sources of household air pollution in sub-Saharan Africa, with severe health consequences for the population, according to the World Bank. Now, an initiative to promote climate-friendly cooking in the region is introducing stoves that use less charcoal and firewood to improve air quality. Juma Majanga reports from Nakuru, Kenya.

title: Kenya-Haiti mission will be armed with prayers
description: Evangelical pastors have been taking a key role in preparations for Kenya's mission to tackle gang violence in Haiti. David Doyle of Reuters has more.

title: Nairobi's Chinatowns: a reflection of greater Chinese presence
description: Chinatowns are recognizable all over the world, either by their big red gates or streets lined with Chinese restaurants and stores. In Nairobi, Kenya, there are several Chinatowns of different sizes scattered around the city. VOA Nairobi bureau chief, Mariama Diallo took a stroll in one of them and has this story.

title: Kenyan lawmakers probe alleged abuse by British forces
description: A Kenyan parliamentary committee is visiting central Kenya to hear from locals about the conduct of a British Army training unit that is accused of human rights violations, including the unresolved death of a woman more than ten years ago. The Kenya National Human Rights Commission prompted the inquiry by petitioning parliament to hold the British army accountable for alleged human rights abuses. Mohammed Yusuf reports

title: Kenya President Ruto and US President Biden hold a joint press conference
description: US President Joe Biden has named Kenya as a non-NATO ally, making it the first sub-Saharan African country to receive that designation. Kenyan President William Ruto is on a state visit to the United States. VOA’s Douglas Mpuga spoke with political analyst David Monda for an analysis of what was said during the joint press conference.

title: President Biden announces the designation of Kenya as a major non-NATO ally
description: U.S. President Biden said Thursday he will designate Kenya a major non-NATO ally during Kenyan President Ruto's state visit. What does a non-NATO ally designation mean in practical terms? VOA’s Carol Van Dam put that question to Cameron Hudson, in the Africa Program at the Center for Strategic and International Studies.

title: US President Joe Biden welcomes Kenya President William Ruto to the White House
description: Kenya’s President William Ruto, on a state visit to the U.S., was welcomed to the White House by President Joe Biden on Thursday in a ceremony filled with pomp, music, and military honor guards. VOA’s Yeheyes Wuhib spoke with White House correspondent Anita Powell, who was at the welcoming ceremony, for more on President Ruto’s state visit.

title: Kenya’s President Ruto appeals for US security support, defends Haiti mission
description: Kenyan President William Ruto has appealed for US support to strengthen democracy and security in Africa, reduce debt, and enhance its investment in the institutions of Africa integration. Ruto spoke Thursday when President Joe Biden welcomed him to the White House for the first state visit by an African president to the White House since 2008. Ruto defended his decision to deploy Kenyan police to Haiti.

title: Biden says US will name Kenya "major non-NATO ally," launches Nairobi-Washington Vision
description: U.S. President Joe Biden on Thursday announced that his administration is working with Congress to name Kenya as "a major non-NATO ally" during a joint press conference at the White House, saying it "is a fulfilment of years of collaboration." Biden also announced the launch of what he called the "Nairobi-Washington Vision" that will assemble international financial institutions and nations to mobilize more resources for debt-ridden countries like the East African nation. "These are big goals, it will take time to see lasting progress," he said. Ruto, on his part, expressed "deep concern" over what he said are the "accelerating drift toward regimes indifferent to democratic values," adding that he believes it is time for the United States, along with Kenya, to rally "like-minded democratic countries to set up the course for democracy."

title: Kenya President Ruto’s state visit to the U.S. aims to strengthen ties between the countries
description: An expert in international relations security and diplomacy says Kenyan President Ruto’s visit to the U.S. could be a turning point for Kenya. Dr. Edgar Githua from the US International University in Nairobi tells VOA’s Yeheyes Wuhib the state visit is poised to be a turning point for Kenya and is aimed at strengthening ties among the two nations.

title: US to designate Kenya key non-NATO ally
description: Kenyan President William Ruto visited the White House Wednesday, the first day of his three-day state visit. Reuters quotes a source as saying that President Joe Biden is expected to designate Kenya as a major non-NATO ally during Ruto’s visit. Johnnie Carson served as United States ambassador to several African countries, including Kenya. He tells VOA’s James Butty, Ruto’s visit symbolizes the strong connection between the United States and Kenya.

title: Kenya’s President comes to Washington for a state visit
description: Kenya’s President William Ruto is in Washington, D.C. for a state visit. A White House official says Ruto and U.S. President Joe Biden will discuss ways to strengthen the two countries’ cooperation in several areas. VOA’s James Shimanyula has more from Nairobi.

title: Kenya’s President Ruto will not address US Congress
description: The decision by U.S. House Speaker Mike Johnson’s to not invite Kenyan President William Ruto to a joint meeting of Congress when he comes to Washington later this month has disappointed many people. VOA’s Carol Van Dam has more from Washington.

title: US charity helps Kenyan communities build resilience to climate change
description: The U.N. environmental agency says Africa is the lowest contributor of global greenhouse emissions yet remains the most vulnerable to the effects of climate change. A U.S. charity called GiveDirectly is helping some African communities build resilience. Juma Majanga reports from Baringo, Kenya.

title: Kenyan medical worker's strike is only partially over
description: Kenyan doctors are working again but clinical officials and lab workers are still out on strike. Doctor Kahura Mudia, secretary general for the Kenyan Medical Practitioners and Dentists Union, tells VOA’s Yeheyes Wuhib that some issues remain unresolved.

title: Kenyan authorities expect heavy rainfall to continue, flood victims mourn
description: Kenyan authorities say weeks of flooding that have killed over 240 people while displacing over 235,000, are expected to continue through June — developments happening as residents of the East African nation continue attempts to rebuild their lives and mourn loved ones they lost to the disaster. VOA’s Nairobi Bureau Chief Mariama Diallo has more.

title: Kenyans mourn flood victims as government pledges aid
description: With deaths nearing 240 and about 235,000 people displaced, Kenyans are mourning their lost loved ones and trying to rebuild after weeks of heavy rains that resulted in deadly floods and landslides. And it’s not over yet as more rain is expected through June. VOA Nairobi Bureau Chief Mariama Diallo has this report

title: Kenyan doctors end strike after deal with government
description: Kenya’s nearly two-month-old doctors strike ended Wednesday after the doctors signed a back-to-work agreement. They have been on strike for better pay and improved working conditions. President William Ruto appealed to the doctors to reconsider their demand for pay raises because the government could not spend money that it does not have. However, a court gave both sides 48 hours to finalize a back-to-work agreement, or the court would step in and impose a solution. Dr Simon Kigondu, President of the Kenya Medical Association, tells VOA’s James Butty, the strike was worth it because it brought the government and doctors to address the

title: US agency launches climate resilience efforts in Kenya
description: The United States Agency for International Development this week launched a $6 million program to support small businesses and financial institutions in northern Kenya that are looking to implement climate-smart practices and enhance their resilience to climate-related challenges. The region suffers from recurring droughts; when it does rain, it often floods, causing people to lose their livelihoods. Mohammed Yusuf reports on the USAID program goals.

title: US Speaker urged to invite Kenya’s President to address Congress
description: The US House Committee on Foreign Affairs has put in a formal request to Speaker Mike Johnson to invite Kenyan President William Ruto to address a joint session of the Congress. President Ruto is scheduled to visit the United States on an official state visit on May 23, 2024, the first time in two decades that an African president has been accorded a state visit in the US. VOA’s Douglas Mpuga has the details.

title: Group empowers women to bridge technology divide in rural Kenya
description: Kenya’s Center for Women Empowerment in Technology is helping to bridge the technology divide in rural areas in the East African country. Judy Makaria, co-founder and CEO of the group, tells VOA’s Peter Clottey that its core aim is to strengthen the role of women and to integrate them in the use of technology in socio-economic development.

title: Flooding devastates poor Kenyan communities
description: The latest reports from Kenya say floods have claimed the lives of almost 170 people, while more than 200,000 people have been affected by the disaster. Jack Oduor, a community organizer in Nairobi’s Mathare slums, talks with VOA's Paul Ndiho about the devastating impact of the floods on his community.

title: East Africa floods bring death and destruction
description: Heavy rains continue to pound a large portion of East Africa, causing death and devastation. At least 240 people have died in floods in recent days In Kenya and Tanzania. Tens of thousands of people have been displaced. Police said Monday that at least 40 people died when a dam burst in western Kenya. VOA's Reuben Kyama reports from Nairobi.

title: Doctors fired in Kenya
description: Dr. Dennis Miskellah, deputy secretary of Kenya Medical Practitioners Pharmacists and Dentists Union says members of the group will not be intimidated or bullied into returning to work until their concerns are addressed. VOA's Peter Clottey spoke with Dr. Miskellah for an update in the Kenya doctor’s strike.

title: Kenya flooding worsens healthcare crisis
description: Several people were reported missing Sunday evening after a boat capsized in Mororo, Bangale in Tana River County in Kenya. TJeffrey Okoro, the Executive Director of CFK Africa, an NGO that works with community members in Kenya, tells VOA’s James Butty the crisis in access to healthcare has been compounded by major flooding across the country.

title: Kenya to host South Sudan peace talks
description: A South Sudan official has confirmed that Kenya will host peace talks soon between the government and so-called holdout armed groups. Nathaniel Oyet Pierrino, Deputy Chairman of the SPLM-IO, tells VOA’s James Butty he’s disappointed that the Kenyan mediator who visited Juba over the weekend did not meet with South Sudan First Vice President Riek Machar.

title: Military equipment acquisition questioned following helicopter crash that killed Kenya’s defense chief
description: A security expert in Kenya is expressing concern about political decisions behind the country's acquisition of military equipment following the launch of an investigation into the helicopter crash that killed the country’s military chief, General Francis Ogolla and nine others. Retired Major General Charles Mwanzia in the Kenyan capital, Nairobi, spoke with VOA's Peter Clottey.

title: Inquiry into death of General Francis Ogolla, Chief of Kenya’s Defense Forces
description: Kenyan President William Ruto has called for a thorough and unhindered investigation into the helicopter crash that killed the Kenyan Chief of Defense Forces General Francis Ogolla. General Ogolla and nine other military personnel died last Thursday when their helicopter crashed in the North Rift region of the country. VOA’s James Butty has more.

title: Kenya’s President Ruto mourns Army chief killed in helicopter crash
description: Kenya is mourning the death of its Chief of Defense Forces General Francis Ogolla and nine other military personnel on Thursday. They had been inspecting the North Rift region where the military is conducting an operation against banditry when their helicopter crashed. President William Ruto has declared three days of national mourning beginning Friday.

title: Kenyan Health Care Business Brings Low-Cost Ultrasound to Expectant Mothers
description: For most pregnant women in the slums of Nairobi, ultrasound services are an unaffordable luxury. Now, a Kenyan health care business is using portable, low-cost ultrasound systems to give expectant mothers a chance to see their babies and detect any health problems before the delivery day. Victoria Amunga reports from Nairobi. Videographer: Jimmy Makhulo

title: Kenyan Entrepreneur Addresses Plastic Pollution
description: A Kenyan company is addressing packaging, one of the world’s biggest plastic pollution challenges, by producing toxic chemical-free, composable food products from agricultural waste. VOA’s Juma Majanga has more in this file that was produced from Thika, Kenya.

title: Kenyan Marathon Star Kiptum, Coach Killed in Car Crash
description: Kenyan marathon star Kelvin Kiptum and his coach were killed in a traffic accident in the Rift Valley on Sunday, cutting short the promising career of the only man to have run the endurance classic in less than two hours and one minute. Rachel Graham of Reuters reports.

title: Kenyan Entrepreneur Uses Indigenous Grains to Foster Environmental Sustainability
description: Kenyan entrepreneurs are attempting to promote the consumption of indigenous grains such as millet and sorghum, especially to younger generations who believe the food stuffs are for the poor. For more, reporter Juma Majanga filed this report.

title: Kenya Cult Leader, Associates Charged with 191 Murders
description: Kenyan cult leader, Paul Mackenzie, and 29 of his associates on Tuesday were charged with 191 murders following allegations that the self-proclaimed religious leader ordered members of his church to starve themselves and their children to ensure that they can get into heaven. Reuters’ David Doyle has more.

title: Kenya Company Turns Flip-Flops Into Sustainable Art
description: Millions of flip-flops end up in oceans, waterways, dumpsites and landfills all over the world. A Kenya-based company has found creative and sustainable ways to reuse them. VOA Nairobi bureau chief Mariama Diallo visited their warehouse located in Karen, about 45 minutes from the city center. Camera: Amos Wangua

title: Kenyan Journalist Spotlights Women Challenges
description: A Kenyan journalist is running a publication which exclusively reports on issues affecting women. Her publication, Woman Kenya Network, is aimed to helping women to tell their stories in a society that they say downplays their issues. Victoria Amunga reports from Nairobi.

title: Nairobi Glows as Kenyans Celebrate the Festive Season Despite Challenges
description: For many Kenyans, 2023 has been a tough year, and some residents in the country's capital say they are trying to make ends meet at a time when they would normally travel outside the city and spend time with friends and family. This year, the Kenyan government imposed strict new tax laws, increasing the cost of living, and causing citizens to feel the pinch deep in their pockets. But many Kenyans are still determined to share the joy and warmth of the festive season.

title: Kenyan Conservationists Propose Bird-Friendly Infrastructure as Species Decline
description: Conservationists in Kenya warn that nearly all the country's 103 species of raptors, also known as predatory birds, have declined. These wildlife advocates are now proposing the construction of bird-friendly infrastructure to avert possible extinction. For VOA, Francis Ontomwa has this report from Nakuru, Kenya.

title: Urban Farming Improves Food Security in Kenya
description: As populations swell in cities around the world, urban food security has become a growing problem. In Nairobi, urban farming technology is being used to help ease the food shortage problem. Juma Majanga reports from Nairobi. Camera: Amos Wangwa

title: Electrical Wires, Poles Pose Threat to Rare Birds in Kenya
description: As nearly all of Kenya’s 103 species of raptors decline in population, wildlife advocates are proposing the construction of bird-friendly infrastructure to avert possible extinction. Francis Ontomwa has this report from Nakuru, Kenya. (Camera: Amos Wangwa)

title: China’s Nairobi Embassy Hosts Food Extravaganza to Boost Kenya Ties
description: While experts continue to debate over the impact of loans and trade relations between China and Kenya, the Asian nation’s embassy in the East African nation’s capital, Nairobi, recently launched a food extravaganza focused on boosting cultural ties between the two. For VOA, Victoria Amunga reports from Nairobi.

title: Kenya Makes Strides Towards Eradicating HIV/AIDS by 2030
description: Over one million people in Kenya are living with HIV as the East African nation grapples with high infection rates. Kenya, however, has seen a 78% reduction in new infections and a 57% decrease in AIDS-related deaths. Health officials say they aim to eliminate the pandemic by 2030. For VOA, Juma Majanga reports from Nairobi.

title: Young Africans Hope to Address Climate Challenges Through Training Program
description: Fifty young innovators and leaders from 19 African countries attended a three-week leadership and professional development training program in Ghana’s capital, Accra. Sponsored by the U.S. government, the Young African Leaders Initiative, or YALI, program challenges them to find technology-focused social and business solutions to climate challenges. Isaac Kaledzi has more from Accra.

title: Sole Female Ambulance Driver in Kenyan Refugee Camp Defies Norms
description: Batula Ali is the only woman ambulance driver in Kenya’s largest refugee camp, Dadaab. Ahmed Hussein met Ali and reports from Garissa County, Kenya about breaking gender norms and societal expectations.

title: Kenyan Students Make Flour From Grass
description: Students from Kabarak University in Kenya have developed a method for turning grass into flour that can be consumed by humans. The flour will be used to make ugali — a dish commonly made from cornmeal — since grain has become too expensive for many families. Juma Majanga reports from Nairobi.

title: Kenyan Entrepreneur Addresses Water Shortages During Dry Seasons
description: As Kenya prepares for heavy rains forecasted to occur in November and December, water-harvesting and recycling technology developed by a Kenyan entrepreneur could help reduce water shortages during drier times of the year. Juma Majanga reports from Isinya, Kenya.

title: Britain’s King Charles III Set for Kenya Four-Day Visit
description: King Charles III is scheduled to start his four-day visit to Kenya on Tuesday — his first trip to Africa since becoming king — during which he will address several issues, among them Britain’s colonial past with the East African nation. For more VOA’s Nairobi Bureau Chief Mariama Diallo filed this report.

title: Kenyan Radio Broadcaster Promotes ‘Solutions Journalism’ to Address Social Problems
description: Henix Obuchunju, a Kenyan radio broadcaster that predominantly focuses on social issues like gender-based violence, GBV, is calling on African media practitioners to focus on ‘solutions journalism.’ Obuchunju says the genre is a better way to address societal problems across Africa while capitalizing on the increased usage of social media platforms such as TikTok, for communications. For more, reporter Victoria Amunga filed this report from Kenya’s capital, Nairobi.

title: Invasive Plant Worsens Drought in Northern Kenya
description: Drought-stricken Northern Kenya faces the worst dry spell in 40 years, with more than 5 million people affected. Worse still, a relentless invasive plant is unleashing even more devastation on the environment, livestock and livelihoods. Francis Ontomwa reports from Isiolo, Kenya.

title: Ruto Reacts to UN Resolution Approval of Kenya Led Forces for Haiti Gangs
description: Kenyan President William Ruto Tuesday expressed delight after the United Nations Security Council on Monday voted in favor of deploying an international force led by the East African nation to Haiti to fight increasing violent crimes perpetuated by gangs in the Caribbean nation.

title: Kenyans Divided Over Sending Force to Haiti
description: Some Kenyans have expressed concern over a government proposal to send 1,000 police officers to Haiti as part of an international force led by the East African nation, mandated with addressing violent crime in the Caribbean nation. For more, VOA’s Nairobi Bureau Chief Mariama Diallo filed this report.

title: Kenya’s Longhorn Publishers Helps Students Using Artificial Intelligence
description: Longhorn Publishers, a Kenya-based publishing outlet, is using its LoHo Learning platform to help students from different financial backgrounds gain access to quality education using Artificial Intelligence technology, popularly known as A.I. Through the platform, students will have access to learning materials at a fraction of the cost, sparing them from spending over $100 annually on textbooks For more, Victoria Amunga produced this report from Kenya’s capital, Nairobi.

title: Global Humanitarian Group Helps Kenyans Fight Climate Change
description: The charity group Mercy Corps is helping rural communities in Kenya preserve rangelands and protect themselves against the impact of climate change. For more, reporter Ahmed Hussein produced this report from Wajir County, Kenya.

title: Kenya’s Ruto Addresses 78th UNGA
description: Kenya’s President William Ruto addresses the 78th session of the United Nations General Assembly in New York.

title: Kenyan Activist Calls for TikTok Ban
description: Bob Ndolo, a petitioner with Kenya’s “Ban TikTok” movement has called on President William Ruto’s administration to ban the popular Chinese mobile application. Ndolo says he wants Kenya to ban the app because “you find young girls that you call your sister, your auntie or mother, all there half naked.” For more, reporter Francis Ontomwa produced this report from Kenya’s capital, Nairobi.

title: Kenyan Religious Leaders Protest LGBTQ Rights
description: Kenyan religious leaders Wednesday took to the streets of Mombasa, a port city, to protest a ruling passed Tuesday by the nation’s supreme court that reaffirmed the LGBTQ community’s right to association. Protestors are calling on President William Ruto to follow in the footsteps of his Ugandan counterpart, Yoweri Museveni, who has condemned LGBTQ relations, despite criticism from Western leaders who regard the matter as a human rights violation.
